key_points: Vice President Kamala Harris announces a $1.5 billion investment to grow and diversify the U.S. health care workforce.
The funding will support the National Health Service Corps, Nurse Corps, and Substance Use Disorder Treatment and Recovery programs.
Thanks to the American Rescue Plan, this initiative will support over 22,700 health care providers.
More than 23.6 million patients in the U.S. receive care from clinicians within these programs.
The initiative aims to address racial and ethnic disparities in health care professions and outcomes.
It responds to a projected shortage of up to 60,000 primary care doctors, dentists, and psychiatrists over the next decade in the U.S.
The federal government plans to award $330 million in additional funding for primary care education to help meet these needs.
The investments are in line with recommendations from the Presidential COVID-19 Health Equity Task Force.
This funding is part of the Biden-Harris Administrationâ€™s broader efforts to center equity in the COVID-19 response.
$785 million was announced earlier for equity-focused programs and initiatives as part of these efforts.
